image.altText: Former Queensland Health acting director-general Shaun Drummond

items.synopsis: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says Shaun Drummond's decision to quit as Queensland Health director-general is his own, and that when he was appointed last October he said he would not stay for the full term.

title.children: Queensland Health boss resigns days after disagreement with minister

title.children: Lobbying firm allegedly planned to funnel money to Stuart Robert in return for favours, former employee claims

title.children: Inflation falls sharply, 'soft enough to see the RBA halt' rate rises

image.altText: Three-year-old William Tyrrell has been missing from his NSW mid north coast home since late last week.

items.synopsis: The foster mother is maintaining she has nothing to do with William's disappearance as detectives ask the public prosecutor to consider charges relating to hiding the toddler's body.

title.children: William Tyrrell's foster mother demands to see all evidence against her after police recommend charges

image.altText: Bill Shorten at a press conference

items.synopsis: Stressing that no current NDIS participants will be removed from the scheme, NDIS Minister Bill Shorten says reforms to the scheme may lead to fewer future entrants with psychosocial disability, as the government seeks to curb growth by 27,000 over the next few years.

title.children: Fewer people with psychosocial disability may be added to NDIS, as minister flags 27,000 to be diverted under reforms

image.altText: Army tanks driving in a paddock under a blue sky.

items.synopsis: Australian soldiers were training alongside Japanese and US forces when two military vehicles rolled over in north Queensland.

title.children: Soldiers and Marines taken to hospital after vehicle rollover during defence training exercise

image.altText: A man wearing dark glasses walking outdoors with his head bowed.

items.synopsis: The NSW District Court hears ex-Newtown Jets rugby league player is guilty of carnal knowledge, related to sexual activity with one of his high school students in the 1980s.

title.children: Former Sydney teacher Chris Dawson found guilty of sexual relationship with student

image.altText: A black and white graphic of the two men against a Russian map with a red semi-circle behind them.

items.synopsis: Recent developments in Russia raise serious questions about the future of President Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine. Join our live Q&A as our experts unpack your questions.

title.children: Is Putin in trouble? Join our experts to discuss the latest struggle for power inside the Kremlin

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Was the Wagner attack against Russia vital for Ukraine's counteroffensive and did it have much effect during the short time period? - Will Hi Will, Thanks for your question. No, Ukraine's counteroffensive has not depended on the move by Yevgeny Prigozhin in Russia. I don't think the leaders in Kyiv would have minded watching their invaders fight among themselves, but their counteroffensive would have carried on even if it didn't happen. Prigozhin's mutiny was a distraction for Russia's leaders and that may have opened up some opportunities for Ukraine in the field, but as you say, it was over very quickly. Two days after the aborted march on Moscow, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said: "Today in all sectors, our soldiers made advances. It is a happy day." But as Mick Ryan warned earlier in the week, there is the potential that the instability in Russia and Prigozhin's questioning of military strategy leads Putin to double down and target vulnerable citizens and infrastructure inside Ukraine.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Impact on Ukraine's counteroffensive

children.content: Was the Wagner attack against Russia vital for Ukraine's counteroffensive and did it have much effect during the short time period?
- Will
Hi Will,
Thanks for your question.
No, Ukraine's counteroffensive has not depended on the move by

Yevgeny Prigozhin in Russia. I don't think the leaders in Kyiv would have minded watching their invaders fight among themselves, but their counteroffensive would have carried on even if it didn't happen.
Prigozhin's mutiny was a distraction for Russia's leaders and that may have opened up some opportunities for Ukraine in the field, but as you say, it was over very quickly.
Two days after the aborted march on Moscow, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said: "Today in all sectors, our soldiers made advances. It is a happy day."

But as Mick Ryan warned earlier in the week, there is the potential that the instability in Russia and Prigozhin's questioning of military strategy leads Putin to double down and target vulnerable citizens and infrastructure inside Ukraine.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Are Russians truly oblivious to wards the death of their men sent to the front line in Ukraine? - Andrew Hi Andrew, Thanks for your question. There are so many factors feeding into the awareness and understanding of Vladimir Putin's war inside his own country. And of course much of that is by his design. Yes, there is a propaganda machine at work that is not reporting death tolls widely or accurately, but there are other dynamics too. Earlier in the year, Western officials said it was likely 200,000 Russians had been injured or killed in the war, with at least 40,000 killed. At the time, the analysis was that Vladimir Putin's support could probably sustain that. And when the partial mobilisation happened in September, we learnt that it targeted ethnic minorities in disadvantaged regions - hardly the centres of the President's power base. So while some Russians are likely oblivious, I don't think that can be said for everyone. I think there are some regions and communities disproportionately impacted who will have buried many of their sons. But in Moscow and St Petersburg, I think there is more tolerance for the deaths because they appear as a number on a page. I wrote about the communities impacted by the mobilisation last year:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are Russians aware of the death toll?

featuredLink.title: How Putin's partial mobilisation is allegedly targeting Russia's ethnic minorities and low-income regions

children.content: Are Russians truly oblivious to wards the death of their men sent to the front line in Ukraine?
- Andrew
Hi Andrew,
Thanks for your question.
There are so many factors feeding into the awareness and understanding of Vladimir Putin's war inside his own country. And of course much of that is by his design.
Yes, there is a propaganda machine at work that is not reporting death tolls widely or accurately, but there are other dynamics too.

Earlier in the year, Western officials said it was likely 200,000 Russians had been injured or killed in the war, with at least 40,000 killed. At the time, the analysis was that Vladimir Putin's support could probably sustain that.
And when the partial mobilisation happened in September, we learnt that it targeted ethnic minorities in disadvantaged regions - hardly the centres of the President's power base.

So while some Russians are likely oblivious, I don't think that can be said for everyone. I think there are some regions and communities disproportionately impacted who will have buried many of their sons. But in Moscow and St Petersburg, I think there is more tolerance for the deaths because they appear as a number on a page.
I wrote about the communities impacted by the mobilisation last year:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Did the failed mutiny actually make Putin's position stronger? The strongest private army and loudest critic of the Kremlin were eliminated, didn’t it play out like Putin would have hoped a potential coup might go? - Marc Hi Marc, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to military strategist Mick Ryan, who writes: The coup ultimately has not made Putin stronger. While it might have removed Wagner as a threat (for now) the weekend was not about overthrowing Putin but more about a cry for help from Prigozhin. That said, the slow reaction of Putin and the security authorities has damaged Putin’s standing and revealed what many Russian experts have been describing for some time as a brittleness in the Russian system. For a far better analysis than I could ever provide, I recommend Peter Tesch’s latest article at the ASPI Strategist. Peter has been, and remains, a superb servant of our nation, was our ambassador to Moscow, and is a very deep and broad expert on Russia issues.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Did the failed mutiny make Putin's position stronger?

children.content: Did the failed mutiny actually make Putin's position stronger? The strongest private army and loudest critic of the Kremlin were eliminated, didn’t it play out like Putin would have hoped a potential coup might go? -
Marc
Hi Marc, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to military strategist
Mick Ryan
, who writes:
The coup ultimately has not made Putin stronger. While it might have removed Wagner as a threat (for now) the weekend was not about overthrowing Putin but more about a cry for help from Prigozhin.

That said, the slow reaction of Putin and the security authorities has damaged Putin’s standing and revealed what many Russian experts have been describing for some time as a brittleness in the Russian system. For a far better analysis than I could ever provide, I recommend
Peter Tesch’s latest article at the ASPI Strategist
. Peter has been, and remains, a superb servant of our nation, was our ambassador to Moscow, and is a very deep and broad expert on Russia issues.

items.synopsis: The latest monthly consumer price indicator shows inflation eased sharply to 5.6 per cent over the 12 months to May, down from 6.8 per cent in April. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Future interest rate rises uncertain as inflation hits 13-month low of 5.6pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More signs of the slowing economy. Property analysts CoreLogic says the rate of loss-making home sales rose over the first three months of the year as home prices decreased. However, the vast majority of homes still made a profit on their resale with a median nominal gain of $276,500 nationally. The median loss was $40,000. CoreLogic's Pain & Gain report found the percentage of dwellings that made a gain on their resale declined for the third quarter in a row to 92.3 per cent from a high of 94.2 per cent over the three months to May 2022. And an increasing number of homes sold had been owned for less than two years. Here's Eliza Owen, head of research at CoreLogic: “Such short selling times that involve sellers incurring a loss may be considered unusual, because  hold periods typically increase during housing value downturns, as sellers try to avoid making a loss,”  Ms Owen says. “The implication may be that some sellers are choosing to incur a loss from resale in order to avoid  particularly high mortgage repayments in the current rate-hiking environment." Profit making sales were highest in Hobart, Canberra and Adelaide. Darwin, Perth, Sydney and Melbourne saw an increase in loss making sales, with 10.7 per cent of sales in Sydney making a loss over the March quarter. Nearly 30 per cent of homes were sold at a loss in Darwin.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fewer homes sold at a profit

children.content: More signs of the slowing economy.
Property analysts CoreLogic says the rate of loss-making home sales rose over the first three months of the year as home prices decreased.
However, the vast majority of homes still made a profit on their resale with a median nominal gain of $276,500 nationally.
The median loss was $40,000.
CoreLogic's Pain
Gain report found the percentage of dwellings that made a gain on their resale declined for the third quarter in a row to 92.3 per cent from a high of 94.2 per cent over the three months to May 2022.
And an increasing number of homes sold had been owned for less than two years.
Here's Eliza Owen, head of research at CoreLogic:

“Such short selling times that involve sellers incurring a loss may be considered unusual, because  hold periods typically increase during housing value downturns, as sellers try to avoid making a loss,”  Ms Owen says.
“The implication may be that some sellers are choosing to incur a loss from resale in order to avoid  particularly high mortgage repayments in the current rate-hiking environment."
Profit making sales were highest in Hobart, Canberra and Adelaide.
Darwin, Perth, Sydney and Melbourne saw an increase in loss making sales, with 10.7 per cent of sales in Sydney making a loss over the March quarter.
Nearly 30 per cent of homes were sold at a loss in Darwin.

props.alt: Percentage of home sales made at a loss

children.content: Home sales
(CoreLogic)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some reaction from major business groups after annual inflation pulled back to 5.6 per cent in May. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the retreat in inflation will bring some comfort to small business. ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander: “After experiencing 12 interest rate increases, declining consumer spending, and a surge in input costs, it’s good news for small businesses that inflation is returning to its downward trend." “Many small businesses are seeing their costs rise to the point where they have no choice but to increase their prices to maintain operations." Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox says the drop in inflation is encouraging, but more rate hikes will likely be needed. "While encouraging for both households and businesses, and bearing in mind that the monthly ABS excludes some items, we are not there yet. " "Sticking on the path to target inflation will require continued restraint in price setting and wage negotiations by businesses, governments and employees." "With GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, there is very little scope for further slowing without tipping the economy into contraction."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business reaction to cooler inflation

children.content: Here's some reaction from major business groups after annual inflation pulled back to 5.6 per cent in May.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the retreat in inflation will bring some comfort to small business.
ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander:
“After experiencing 12 interest rate increases, declining consumer spending, and a surge in input costs, it’s good news for small businesses that inflation is returning to its downward trend."
“Many small businesses are seeing their costs rise to the point where they have no choice but to increase their prices to maintain operations."
Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox says the drop in inflation is encouraging, but more rate hikes will likely be needed.
"While encouraging for both households and businesses, and bearing in mind that the monthly ABS excludes some items, we are not there yet. "
"Sticking on the path to target inflation will require continued restraint in price setting and wage negotiations by businesses, governments and employees."
"With GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, there is very little scope for further slowing without tipping the economy into contraction."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Capital Economics thinks the slowdown in inflation is not fast enough to prevent further rate hikes by the RBA. And Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia Pacific at Capital Economics, believes the RBA's war on inflation could end in recession. "The sharp fall in inflation in May raises the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will not raise rates any further at the upcoming meeting in July, but we still think that mounting upside risks to inflation will prompt it to press ahead." "With the labour market still very tight, unit labour cost growth surging and the housing market bouncing bank with a vengeance, we suspect the Reserve Bank will press ahead with another rate hike next week." Capital Economics forecasts the official cash rate will peak at 4.85 per cent by September, and then the Reserve Bank will cut rates next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA to press on with rate rises

children.content: Capital Economics thinks the slowdown in inflation is not fast enough to prevent further rate hikes by the RBA.
And Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia Pacific at Capital Economics, believes the RBA's war on inflation could end in recession.

"The sharp fall in inflation in May raises the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will not raise rates any further at the upcoming meeting in July, but we still think that mounting upside risks to inflation will prompt it to press ahead."

"With the labour market still very tight, unit labour cost growth surging and the housing market bouncing bank with a vengeance, we suspect the Reserve Bank will press ahead with another rate hike next week."
Capital Economics forecasts the official cash rate will peak at 4.85 per cent by September, and then the Reserve Bank will cut rates next year.
